authors: Qianli Ma, Chang Guo, Zhiheng Tian, Siyu Wang, Jipeng Xiao, Yuanhao Yue, Zhipeng Zhang
keywords: multi-agent framework, rebuttal generation, evidence-centric planning, peer review process, AI, natural language processing
summary: Introducing REBUTTALAGENT, a multi-agent framework that reframes rebuttal generation as an evidence-centric planning task, ensuring responses are anchored in verifiable evidence and outperforming baselines in coverage, faithfulness, and strategic coherence.

filename: 2601.14172v1_Human Values in a Single Sentence Moral Presence H.pdf
title: Human Values in a Single Sentence: Moral Presence, Hierarchies, and Transformer Ensembles on the Schwartz Continuum
authors: Víctor Yeste, Paolo Rosso
keywords: sentence-level identification, Schwartz motivational continuum, human value detection, moral presence, transformer ensembles, DeBERTa-base, instruction-tuned LLMs, ensemble models
summary: This study explores sentence-level identification of 19 values in the Schwartz motivational continuum, focusing on the challenges of sparse moral cues and class imbalance, and evaluates various models including DeBERTa-base and instruction-tuned LLMs.

title: A model of errors in transformers
authors: Suvrat Raju, Praneeth Netrapalli
keywords: LLMs, error rate, attention mechanism, task complexity, effective field theory, prompt construction
summary: The paper studies the error rate of large language models on deterministic tasks, deriving a two-parameter model to predict accuracy and empirically validating it.

title: Toward Efficient Agents: A Survey of Memory, Tool Learning, and Planning
authors: Xiaofang Yang, Lijun Li, Heng Zhou, Tong Zhu, Xiaoye Qu, Yuchen Fan, Qianshan Wei, Rui Ye, Li Kang, Yiran Qin, Zhiqiang Kou, Daizong Liu, Qi Li, Ning Ding, Siheng Chen, Jing Shao
keywords: Agents, Efficiency, Agent Memory, Tool Learning, Planning
summary: This paper investigates the efficiency of agentic systems from the perspectives of memory, tool learning, and planning, focusing on cost metrics like latency and tokens, and discusses high-level principles and benchmarks for efficiency.

title: Self-Proposed Interventions Enable Credit Assignment in LLM Reasoning
authors: Matthew Y. R. Yang, Hao Bai, Ian Wu, Gene Yang, Amrith Setlur, Aviral Kumar
keywords: large language models, reinforcement learning, credit assignment, intervention training, mathematical reasoning
summary: Intervention Training (InT) enables large language models to perform fine-grained credit assignment by proposing targeted corrections to their reasoning traces, improving accuracy significantly over standard reinforcement learning methods.

title: MASCOT: Towards Multi-Agent Socio-Collaborative Companion Systems
authors: Yiyang Wang, Yiqiao Jin, Alex Cabral, Josiah Hester

summary: MASCOT is a framework for multi-agent socio-collaborative companions that addresses persona collapse and social sycophancy through a bi-level optimization strategy, improving persona consistency and social contribution.

title: KAGE-Bench: Fast Known-Axis Visual Generalization Evaluation for Reinforcement Learning
authors: Egor Cherepannov, Daniil Zelezetsky, Alexey K. Kovalev, Aleksandr I. Panov

summary: KAGE-Bench introduces a JAX-native 2D platformer to evaluate visual generalization in reinforcement learning by isolating visual shifts, revealing axis-dependent failures and enabling fast, reproducible experiments.

title: Q-LEARNING WITH ADJOINT MATCHING
authors: Qiyang Li, Sergey Levine
keywords: Q-learning, Adjoint Matching, TD-based reinforcement learning, continuous-action RL, diffusion policy, flow-matching policy, temporal-difference backup, offline RL, offline-to-online RL
summary: Q-learning with Adjoint Matching (QAM) is a novel TD-based reinforcement learning algorithm that efficiently optimizes expressive diffusion or flow-matching policies with respect to a parameterized Q-function, leveraging adjoint matching to avoid numerical instability in backpropagation.
